awd_titl_txt: Developing Laser Postionization to Enhance Mass Spectrometry Imaging
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professors Luke Hanley and Igor L. Bolotin and their group at the University of Illinois at Chicago are improving laser-based methods to image targeted chemical species on the surfaces of samples such as animal or plant tissues, bacterial and fungal biofilms, organic electronic devices, or rocks.  Based on a powerful detection approach know as mass spectrometry (MS), such chemical images are becoming routinely available, and have led to many advances in drug discovery, bioengineering, plant biology, microbiology, consumer electronics, and geology.  However, current methods often lack the ability to provide both detailed molecular structures and high clarity (spatial resolution). The Hanley/Bolotin group is working to improve the sensitivity of the technique and therefore the spatial resolution.  The research is also providing opportunities for undergraduate students from underrepresented groups to work with the team and acquire important job skills.

Matrix assisted laser desorption/ionization (MALDI) and secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS) are currently the most widely used strategies for sub-micrometer resolution MS imaging.  Both of these methods can suffer from insufficient signal as the probe size is reduced, differential ion formation that misses some analytes, fragmentation at higher lateral resolution, and/or sample charging effects that deform images. The Hanley/Bolotin group is working to couple laser postionization to MALDI as a means of efficiently ionizing the large fraction of the desorbed material that is uncharged, thereby providing signal enhancement needed to improve lateral resolution and improving detection of species that otherwise ionize poorly or not at all.  Vacuum ultraviolet postionization (using a fluorine excimer laser) and declustering using gas-phase collisions in the desorption plume are being evaluated as means of enhancing sensitivity.  The team is also assessing whether resolution gains already demonstrated with sub-500 femtosecond pulses can be leveraged with gains from changing the laser wavelength and/or declustering. These strategies are all being evaluated with test samples that include bacterial biofilms. Parallel collaborative studies with Professor Ian Gilmore at the United Kingdom's National Physical Laboratory are assessing whether these gains can be extended to secondary-ion mass spectrometry (SIMS) imaging.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Mass spectrometry (MS) imaging is widely used to analyze disease states within intact biological tissue, novel electronic devices such as new batteries, and in many other applications. MS imaging requires that a target molecule within a solid sample be ejected from the solid and then charged (or ionized). Most MS imaging methods use a single pulse of laser light or ions to cause molecular ejection and ionization. The most popular MS imaging method requires specific methods of preparing the samples which can distort the images obtained and/or obscure the measurement of certain chemical species.

This project explores the use of two separate short pulsed lasers for both the ejection process and the ionization process in MS imaging. A schematic diagram of the apparatus is shown here. This method can provide a more versatile analysis with reduced requirements for sample preparation. Both femtosecond and picosecond lasers were explored for the ejection process, with the work here amongst the only work demonstrating the utility of picosecond lasers emitting at ultraviolet wavelengths. A fluorine excimer laser was also used, but for either direct ionization of the ejected molecule or secondary ionization of the molecule from electrons formed by the laser: the former method was limited to certain molecules while the latter method is much more general.

Most of this work involved experimens performed using sophisticated custom-built instrumentation, but parts of it employed computer calculations in support of the proposed mechanisms of ionization. A poster presentation of this work is shown here. Finally, some comparisons were made to another popular method of MS imaging known as secondary ion mass spectrometry.

These results are also relevantt to the use of picosecond lasers for micromachining. In particular, the ultraviolet picosecond laser pulses explored here are very attractive for machining a variety of materials. There is a large literature on the use of longer and shorter laser pulses for micromachining, but relatively few results reported on the intermediate, but convenient picosecond pulse regime.

This project provided training in advanced chemical analyses and scientific instrumentation to four graduate students, two of whom received their Ph.D. degrees and are now employed domestically, one in a national laboratory and the other working in a company doing biological analyses. A third student has moved into the field of solid state electrolyte battery research and a fourth student is working on biological analyses in a national laboratory: both will receive their Ph.D. degrees in the next year or two.


Last Modified: 04/05/2023
Modified by: Luke Hanley

    Luke Hanley

    Diagrams of LDPI-MS instrument
  • Poster of recent results of project, presented at the Fall Meeting of the American Chemical Society, Chicago, IL August 2022.
    Teodora Zagorac and Luke Hanley
    Public Domain
    Luke Hanley
    Poster Presented at Fall 2022 Meeting of the ACS
